info.name: Reticulospinal tract
info.description: The reticular formation gives origin to multiple descending tracts known as reticulospinal tracts. Originating primarily in the medullary and pontine reticular formation, these tracts have several functions. They relay information from the hypothalamus to the preganglionic neurons at lower levels; thus a lesion of the reticulospinal tract in the lower medulla or spinal cord can produce Horner's syndrome due to disruption of the central control of the sympathetic innervation to the head. These descending tracts also have a major impact on motor control, especially the level of reflex activity that imparts muscle tone and core postural mechanisms; the balance of excitation and inhibition that they impart on lower motor neurons is upset when thes tracts are damaged, leading to hyperactive reflexes and increases in muscle tone. Finally, the raphe spinal tract that is associated with blocking pain at the dorsal horn, is often considered to be part of the reticulospinal tracts.
